questions.question: What is the main role of an operating system?

options.text: To compile high-level code into machine code
To manage hardware resources and provide services to applications
To replace all user applications
To encrypt internet traffic by default

questions.explanation: The OS acts as a resource manager and service layer between hardware and applications.

questions.question: In preemptive scheduling, what can happen to a running process?

options.text: It cannot be interrupted until it exits
It can be paused to let another process run
It immediately gets highest priority permanently
It skips the ready queue forever

questions.explanation: Preemptive scheduling allows the OS to interrupt a process and reschedule CPU time.

questions.question: A race condition most commonly occurs when:

options.text: Multiple threads access shared data without proper synchronization
A hard disk has no free sectors
A process has high priority
A system uses only one user account

questions.explanation: Without synchronization primitives, interleaving can produce inconsistent shared-state results.

questions.question: Which scheduling algorithm is most likely to favor short CPU burst jobs?

options.text: First-Come, First-Served (FCFS)
Round Robin with very large quantum
Shortest Job First (SJF)
Random scheduling

questions.explanation: SJF prioritizes processes with smaller burst times.

questions.question: Why are semaphores used in operating systems?

options.text: To increase monitor resolution
To coordinate access to shared resources
To compress file systems
To rename system calls

questions.explanation: Semaphores provide signaling and mutual exclusion for concurrent tasks.

title: Lecture 2: DBMS and Normalization
topic: Keys, normal forms, and anomaly reduction in relational design.

questions.question: What is a primary key in a relational table?

options.text: An attribute that can contain duplicate values
A field used only for sorting records visually
A unique and non-null identifier for each row
A key that references itself in another table

questions.explanation: A primary key uniquely identifies every tuple and cannot be null.

questions.question: Which issue is normalization primarily trying to reduce?

options.text: Rendering speed in frontend applications
Data redundancy and update anomalies
Database user authentication
Network packet loss

questions.explanation: Normalization organizes attributes to minimize redundancy and inconsistency.

questions.question: A table is in 2NF if it is already in 1NF and:

options.text: Has no partial dependency on a composite key
Contains no foreign keys
Has exactly two columns
Stores all attributes as numeric values

questions.explanation: 2NF removes partial dependency of non-prime attributes on composite keys.

questions.question: A foreign key is used to:

options.text: Uniquely identify rows in the same table only
Link records between related tables
Encrypt a relation schema
Replace the need for indexes

questions.explanation: Foreign keys enforce referential integrity across table relationships.

questions.question: Which normal form removes transitive dependency of non-key attributes?

options.text: 1NF
2NF
3NF
BCNF is the only form that handles this

questions.explanation: 3NF addresses transitive dependencies where non-key attributes depend on other non-key attributes.
